reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buyer beware.  This game is NOT Early Access in any shape or form.

Do not buy this game expecting there will be many improvements/features to come because it is EA, it simply is not.   The game is playable (Windows only) but has many frustrating usability issues, but if you can see past these as it currently stands it might be worth a buy.

However the game is already 3+ years old, I bought it a year before the Steam release.  In the past 2 years updates have occurred at about once per 6 months (see the T&S forums). The lack of communication from the main developer of T&S (the one setting the roadmap) is the worst I have ever experienced. On the forums it is almost non-existant, here on Steam, as you can see, there is no news whatsover since release.

The developer needs to move it from Early Access into a release version ASAP.  That way you as a buyer know exactly what you're getting.  Also, as a released game it is quite acceptable for 1 or 2 updates a year (or less) and minimal communication.  As Early Access it is absolutely not.


Pros:
- Great feeling of creative freedom to build whatever style of fortress you want.
- Nicely generated procedural landscapes to play on.
- Ability to override AI temporarily and move people into position for combat or run away (greatly reduces frustration).
- Excellent music soundtrack.

Cons:
- Micro management is fine to some extent, but having to contiinually change professions of people to get anything built is not fun after the hundredth time.  This may be mitigated slightly once you have more people, but getting more people is not easy (see later points).  Regardless, there is no task priority system whatsoever, very poor for a game of this type.

- Very poor communication of key concepts.  The in game tutorial is very basic.  For example it suggests build roads to get more workers but doesn't explain the additional conditions required to get visitors (tip: it seems to depend on your food levels).  How do you remove designations to build/mine etc, (tip: select build/mine , hold down Shift Alt, and drag over the existing designation).  Why is this not mentioned in the game at any point?

- Farming is extremely confusing and counter intuitive.  In order to increase your food level there seems to be some  hidden magic balance between size and number of fields, number of farmers, skill of farmers and possibly crop type.  If you don't get this balance exactly right eg. you have say too many farmers or too large fields, your food levels will actually drop.  As food is so critical to success in this game (getting more immigrants) , this is frustrating and needs much better explanation.  I've even noticed farmers actually removing plants before they yield any food.

- The game often displays quantities as a total of the mass of all items eg. 8 items with 0.5 mass each is displayed as 4.  In many screens however it often has no indication whether a number indicates mass or straight quantity.  This is ridiculously confusing. How hard is it to add just a 'mass' suffix to all relevant fields?

- Road system is tedious.  You have to manually build roads to the very edge of the map, adjusting the height level for every hill you come across.  This adds nothing to the gameplay, visitors should be able to find their own way to your hall like almost every other similar game.

- Mouse and keyboard view controls are unintuitive.  You scroll the view using the WASD keys with Shift to move faster.  (Default scroll is too slow so I  continually have to use Shift which is painful after a while). You rotate the view by right clicking and moving the mouse.  An improvement would be scrolling via right click on the world/drag and rotate via Q/E keys.  This is simpler,  more accurate and less tiring.

- Mouse wheel zooming is also very flaky, sometimes gentle zooming-in jumps you 10 levels below the surface, zooming out puts you way out above the map.

- New textures are ok for stone, rocks etc but grass is quite ugly in my opinion.  I also have to turn off shadows, not for performance but so I can more easily see elevation changes etc.

I'll revise this if/when any updates occur that address any of these issues.  It's a game with plenty of potential, but it's been in early access" for about 3 years now (way before coming to steam) and the development team seem to just disappear for months at a time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Timber and Stone, in short, is a great but slow game.
Guide your settlers in the steps it takes to build your castle/town/underground refuge/etc.
The game is a balancing act between harvesting resources, training soldiers, and building your defenses. Fail at any of these and watch in horror as something simple like a wolf pack kills off all your settlers, or something as extreme as a horde of skeletons following an evil magician burns your world to the ground.
Its a slow process of mining rock, shaping it and building it into your massive castle, training settlers to be knights outfited with the best armor and weapons, setting up an economy to trade for resources you dont have, and finally reaching a level of safety and refuge for your lazy/weak/overeating, worthless settlers. Its your choice whether to feed them to wolves, or let them stay in the hopes that maybe they will contribute at some point.
The game has a steep learning curve, you will be playing along thinking that your doing fine, then get destroyed because you didnt realize how important feathers were, or maybe you do know how important they are (key ingredient for arrows) but the damn chickens didnt want to shed any. . . either way you can invest a few hours into it, and get wrecked. But if you stick with it (meaning start over and over) for a bit, you will start to feel the satisfaction of successfully raising an army, filling your battlements with archers, polishing up your castle, and building a thriving town. Then let the hordes come, let the goblins chop the forest down, for when they approach your walls, hell will rain down from your archers. And when they charge your gates, greet them with the points of a dozen lances. When the spider monarch shruggs off your arrows, fire balistas at her until she is nothing but crumpled remains.
The game is still a work in progress, there are lots of little things that can irritate the crap out of you, but its worth grinding your teeth and working around them.
The game is very playable as is, but will only be getting better. The devs have proven their loyalty and dedication to the game and Im very excited for the finished product one day far far from now.

*Updated Review*   Please be aware that this game has been abandoned by the developer.   While that phrase gets thrown about a lot,  in this case it is 100% true.    Does that mean this is a bad game?   Depends on what you like and if you are willing to accept the progress that has been made, and understand that there will be no more updates.   Are you still interested?   Then continue reading....


In a nutshell, its a challenging base building game that requires attention to detail, managing your villagers, and protecting them from their own stupidity.

What there is to like about it...

It has a minecraft look and feel about it, blocks with sloped angles.
Base building is simple to understand, and allows for infinite creativity when it comes to design.
Recipes for crafting are explained ahead of time, no need for research.
Definite balance to crafting/fighting/building required,  this creates a true challenge.
The musical score is perfect,  varied and rich in sound.
It can be fast paced at times, and laid back at other times.


What are its problems?

Tutorials are crude, almost cryptic.
Learning curve is deceptively steep.   You can load it up, play it for a few hours, think you have a handle on it, only to watch your village get wiped within minutes by something you didn't plan for.
Building menus and planning menus aren't separated, creating deep menu trees that can confuse players.
Noticle hiccups in the camera behavior, terrain fogging over, and the camera diving below the ground level.


What is it similar to?

Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria, Stone Hearth,  Anno series, Banished.
If you own any of these titles and love the genre, you may want to consider Timber and Stone.   If you've played some of those games, and found it to be tedious, or just not your kinda thing, then pass on Timber and Stone.


Things to be concerned about...

The game has been abandoned by the developer.   So any bugs listed in the forums or mentioned in this review WILL NOT BE FIXED.    There is are no indications that anyone will take over the development of this game.


In conclusion...

Given the state of the game, knowing it will never be updated,  this game is worth $5 to $10 tops.   There are youtube videos that show the games content and how it plays in its current build.   Please take the time to watch some videos and consider the price point prior to purchase.

In addition, there is also the chance the developer has violated the early access agreement, and this game may be removed from the store page.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine when you were a kid and how awesome it would have been if your Lego came to life – that’s kind of what this game is.  You get the freedom to place each block how you want it (with decent tools for creating larger buildings).  Sometimes you have to give orders to your guys one at a time, but part of the charm is the slow burn of starting with a wagon full of goods, a few settlers and getting everything set up the way you want.

The Good:
- Nearly unlimited creativity with a great variety of resources and building materials.
- Enough uniqueness to each villager that you are invested in their wellbeing and frustrated if they die.
- All characters and professions are important, this isn’t just a matter of getting some max level troops and laughing as enemies break against your defenses.

The Neutral:
This game is tough.  Part of the fun is that it is not a pushover, but it’s worth mentioning so you know what you’re getting.  Realize that you will have some settlements wiped out as you learn how to survive.  The difficulty plus a casual pace of play means that at some point a pack of wolves or goblins will tear apart a settlement that you have really grown to like.  There will be little you can do with the frustration other than start over.

The Bad:
- At some point you will probably get frustrated that your soldiers don’t behave like a true RTS game.  Even as you develop a large settlement, the game is still based of a group of villagers surviving and thriving in the wild, not an Age of Empires style battle of armies and the controls reflect this.
- Surprisingly taxing on my system given the graphics level.

I played this game even before it arrived on steam. I probably have around 100 hours already. Cause it was super fun.

While the game is early access expect bugs and pathfinding problems. Selection of your people is a bit harder then other games, but hopefully you can select multiple at the same time eventually rather then just one cause fighting can get a bit tedious and frustrating.

This game is amazing with all its deep building engine and making building seem like a hard long process which building in real life is. I once made a small village and it took so long I felt like everyone mattered and every block placed on my houses felt like an accomplishment in itself. With all the skeletal and goblin bodies outside it trying to get at my villagers. The carnage was great and made me feel like my village was doing its business at keeping out invaders.

When I lost just one member of my community I was heart broken cause thats one less villager farming, building, or making Iron tools which helps extremely. And losing someone thats good at making iron tools sucks. Or a good farmer which sucks to. The game makes your choices impact hard. And the best part is you make your own quests, decisions, choices, who gets accepted into the community. The game has lots of things you can already do. Oh and making camps and also item placing is incredible in this game. Place barrels, crates, campfires, and many things all around the place to make your own personalized areas, locations, camps. Lots of things to do.

This is just my opinion but the reason I played it this long is because there was no fog of war and bodies never disappeared unless you deleted them or gathered what was on them. Now they disappear without that which disapoints me. These two aspects of the game nailed it for me to keep on playing. As there was no annoying blanket of shadow everywhere which made the environments and your villages look amazing in pictures and just looking at it all in adventurer mode.

Although the game itself actually used to be better with no fog of war, and no de-spawning bodies, with battles looking like battlefields. And no dark fog blanket over the world which made pictures and the land looked amazing hopefully they bring these back. Cause honestly its what made me really come back to play this game.

I still recommend it but I wish they hadn't taken out two important aspects of the game out that I loved about it. If they do however bring back those two things (No fog of war and no de-spawning bodies) I'm going to be playing it again. Don't be discouraged about this review. Its personal preference with me and these two things might get added back later as options hopefully.

Early Access Review Conclusion: Not yet - but one day...hopefully.

It's come on a decent way from my last look in but it's worrying to see that many basics have apparently been side-lined in favour of cosmetic improvements - for example the camera controls are awkward - reversed is how I'd describe the method by which you hold the middle mouse button - then pan in the direction you move the mouse - as opposed to as if you're grabbing the ground and moving it like every other RTS I've ever played.

Zooming the mouse is inconsistent - tiny increments followed by 100m (apparent) leap which leaves you apparently buried several feet underground. Panning is the same - not at all smooth.

There seem to be a few AI bugs; my villagers often stand around doing nothing or 'pathing' as they call it - calling out the things they can't mine amount the swathes of things they quite easily could etc.

As per the last time I tried this, you can just about get a functioning village set up - before you get over-run by a horde of wolves/goblins etc and then it's pretty much game over. I think this needs balancing. I'm not new to this sort of game, but I feel cheated when *just surviving* is pretty tough and then you're smacked down by an excession like a 6 strong pack of wolves. Villagers aren't keen on retreating to the strudy-walled 'hall' you make them build and besides, poking at attackers through the walls isn't an option so unless you somehow manage to produce a lot of archers it's going to come down to a club-vs-wolf fight of attrition.

I'm still going to recommend this - BUT NOT YET. Let it get though early access and hopefully iron out the creases first then I think this will be a challenging - but fun little game.

This game is amazing.. Don't let the graphics turn you off. Be prepared though; this game does have a bit of a steep learning curve, but is worth it! The best way to describe this game is putting Minecraft, Banished, and some other games together (build farms, build buildings, make tools/weapons, defend your settlement, build armor/weapons, get resources, etc.) You also trade with a trader than comes in; to do so you need to build roads to the edge of the map (build in all directions from your townhall); these roads also allow immigrants to join your settlement every so often. It's pretty cool that you can build buldings pretty much anyway you want provided you have the materials.

You also have to designate each type of worker; you can do this by pressing U and then assining them different tasks. The maps are HUGE if you select large; I'm amazed by how large it is. The most important thing about this game is it's a blast to play; just be prepared to learn everything as you go; it's not that difficult once you start to understand you need to assign your workers, etc.

The game will automatically pause if one or more of your workers is in range of a goblin, wolf, etc. This is a good thing.. This allows you to unpause if your think your fine, or press U and jump to the worker that is in trouble. On the top of the screen in the beginning you can click on resources, click on each resource, and build the stock level to a certain level (of course you'll need materials, but the game remembers what you set it to.).

Be sure to go to options once you're in the game and change the scrolling speed when you move your mouse around; by default it's setup pretty slow, and also increase the draw distance.

This game is one of my favorites now that I'm figuring it out; keep in mind this game is more for adults whom have played other strategy games. I wouldn't recommend this for kids as it's a bit of a steep learning curve, but you can teach them as well.

Highly recommended, with a caveat: if you like real challenge, you'll love this as-is; if you just like to build, get the no-monsters mod.

I've been playing Timber and Stone for what seems like years now, through many big changes, long before it made it to Steam. The Dev team has been dedicated, and consistently interacting with the community (on their website forum): taking feedback, adding content, polishing, squashing bugs, everything you want out of a good early access project.

The game improves in every update. Do note that updates take a while, but that's only because they're always substantial. There's a lot of content and depth to the game already, though a bit more in terms of crafting and professions would be welcome.

The only three issues I have:

1) the game should have a built-in difficulty-level option. Vanilla, especially in the most recent update, it's tough. Which is great! But sometimes I just want to build, as that's a lot of fun--relaxing fun--too. My ideal case: give several options. Give an option to turn off monster spawning entirely, but allow it to be turned on later in the game (test out those defenses you've built!); give an option to have a very slow buildup; give the current difficulty level, which is tough but achievable (for a while!); give something ridiculously tough.
NOTE: There is a mod, which can be found on their website forum, that turns off the waves of monsters so that you can build. It would just be nice to have this natively.
Devs: consider something like Rimworld's various difficulty options.

2) Once you have quite a few settlers (15+) in a big map, it starts to get sluggish, and the pathing algos stars to struggle. I don't have the newest setup, but an i7-920 + 16GB DDR3 + Radeon 280x isn't terrible. Smaller maps do a lot better. I'm sure that performance will improve as the project goes on.

3) Picking the exact sort of landing site you want for your map is a pain in the butt. There NEEDS to be a search option, a-la Dwarf Fortress.

But again: highly recommended. And as I've already said twice: if you just want to build/expand, get the no-monster mod from their forum!

I have played this game since it was 1.4 and have had alot of fun with it (and still am). I had a few technical problems with my old computer running an AMD, but since I swapped over to an I7 there has been no problem whatsoever.

I have read many forum posts about how hard the game is but I disagree. The game could be even harder. In fact, after a certain point you have your guards setup on patrol routes, you produce more than you consume and your only use of merchants is to get rid of surplus items. The game is most fun before that point, when you have to struggle in order not to starve or get overrun by wolves/goblins.

In short, the game graphics are cute, the UI is ok, sound/music works very good and there seem to be very few bugs. There are some balancing issues to work out, but the game is in a very good state.

If I would wish for something it would be for a way to support save-versions of the same world. Another thing I would like to see is a setting for difficulty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many games have been inspired by Dwarf Fortress, notably the survival building game Minecraft.

While it's easy to craft a single player voxel based game with resources, crafting, and building, it has not been easy to recreate the city building, management, and survival aspects that the source material is so well known for. (We all know the failures of TOWNS and Gnomorial all too well)

If you're unfamiliar with the genre, it's essentially The Sims meets Minecraft

This game takes the genre and does it right. Shying away from limelight to get the details worked out, Timber and Stone is a fantastic game with only improvements ahead of it. There are a few things that have issues (Clunky UI, occasional bugs with designations, and some other things) but they are relatively minor in terms of the overall gameplay.

It makes some concessions from it's inspiration material as well to improve gameplay. Unlike Dwarf Fortress you can individually direct a villager to a location instead of hoping they go there. Each villager bases it's tasks on how close they are vs some sort of priority to make it easy to speed some things along. (although an overall crafting priority/queue would be beneficial). Every villager only has one profession at a time, simplifying designations (but increases initial micro-management until you get enough villagers to properly do each job).


I highly recommend this game as is, as it beats the previously mentioned failures out of the water already and has more to come.

Your settlers dont mind sleeping under the stars (if they sleep at all, as sleep is only required to heal). There is no rain or coldness that would make them uncomfortable.

The UI of this game has to be one of the worst ever created. The amount of clicking, button-pressing and menu-navigating necessary to do even the simplest things such as building a hammer, making your troops move to the enemy or cancel a designation is stunning and turns playing the game into a chore.

You might say that all of this is to be expected, since the game is EA. But there doesnt seem to be much -if any- development going on right now and
the developers seem to be extremely reclusive, none of which makes me very optimistic about the future of this game.

To be fair, despite all of these shortcomings, the game actually IS fun to play, at least for a few hours, but its certainly not worth 20 € the way it is now. There is just too much frustration and disappointment and too little hope for substantial improvement in the near future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At its core, Timber and Stone is a base-building, survival sim game. You control your guys, have them craft and build and survive against enemies and starvation. Plenty of games like it, right?

However, Timber and Stone does something wonderfully different; it does it enjoyably (something many games of this genre fail to do) but most importantly, it does it consistently.

The game is fun from beginning to end; it is insanely hard to come to grips with at first, but that challenge never quite reaches the level of frustration. As you get stronger, you start to be entranced by the desire to build the perfect castle, or town or whatever you're building, as well as fending off attacks from horrible Goblins and a myriad of Undead. When you lose your first settler... trust me, you'll feel it.

The game has been in development for a few years now, going through several iterations, but the developers have never been anything but completely transparent in their development process. We've been clued in from the start, and most of our feedback has been listened to. This is a dev team that is wholly intent on keeping their playerbase happy.

Timber and Stone is both as simple as its name, yet also wonderfully complex and interesting. It's hard, it hurts you emotionally, but it's so damn rewarding to see your town grow and your settlers progress. You do require a certain self-motivation to play, as there is very, VERY little hand-holding, but you will damn well enjoy yourself.

Also, don't let my hours played fool you; I have played... just so many hours of this wonderful game, before it was released to Steam. The developers have been putting off Steam release until it was in a good enough state.

This is one of several ways to survive at start and for a long time: (unless you f-up)

What you need to do is choose a LARGE map size and then find a RIVER (the map is randomly generated so you can enter the same spot every time and get a different map).
What you are looking for is an Island with trees, once you've found one you need to settle down there and start building a wall around it.
This way you won't need to worry that much about enemies easily killing your settlers at the start of the game, and that island could become your very own fortress. Just build a bridge to main land whenever you're ready to expand.
It's also good to start with whatever food farms you've got and expand them, to prevent starvation. (Your food supplies will be very short at start but you'll eventually end up with an abundance of food)

The rest is up to you, good luck and have fun! :)

Timber and Stone falls under the survival simulation genre, and a role that it accepts very well. There are no scary or haunted undertones here, just bare bones sand and grit that is very punishing until you get the hang of the game.

I don’t know how the community or developers feel, but I feel that this game could have easily been called ‘Towns 2’. It plays very similar to town, but with a more intuitive interface, much better graphics, and an actual way to control various jobs and individual unit movement.

The unit leveling system has received an overhaul as well, with various items not only required prerequisites, but appropriate levels in any given profession. This add more value to each unit, since you will not be able to level up every profession on every unit, at least not within the first 10 hours of gameplay (assuming you live the first 10 hours of gameplay).

I took me approximately 4 settlements until I got the hang of the game, which in turn was about 3-4 hours of gameplay.

There is only 1 con for this game….
Game speed options are at: Pause, 1x, 2x.

That’s it; the pace of this game is a little too slow. I feel that there should be a 4x, and 8x.
This program does not slow my computer down, no reason it should progress this slow.

All truth out I bought this game years ago, before it even became part of greenlight.

Do I reccommend this game?  Yes.  But with fair warning!

A:  This is in early access and by no means finished.  Is it playable now?  Yes, but be prepared because there is no tutorial, no explanation of any of the mechanics, and it can be hard to learn what you are doing.     EDIT!!  In truth there is a VERY basic tutorial that simply includes tips that explain some of the mechanics when you create a new game, but you have to make sure you select it.

B: The learning curve can be quite steep.  A note to all new players: Stockpiles are important.  Make sure you try to build at least the masonry and wood piles ASAP before your current ones fill up.  It is very easy to begin mining dirt and have no stone to build the stockpile with, leaving you with no space on your miner(s) for the stone they need to build the stockpile and nowhere to put it.

Other than that this game is great fun.  You start out with a few settlers who are usually experienced in different things and with them you need to build a bustling town.  With the constant threat of wild animals, goblins, and skeletons attacking at night you need to balance the need for food with protection.  Hopefully after a while you can have a nicely defended castle/fort/wood hut/hole-in-the-ground/whatever you want to build, as long as you have the materials.

This game can take a while to get used to, and it will certainly take a while to build a massive town, but in my opinion it is worth it, as long as you can find a tutorial or something on Youtube or elsewhere on the internet.

Enjoyable game, I had lots of fun playing it and figureing out how to play. but as of late 2015, game development stalled for unspecified reasons. leaving the game playable. fun but lacking the features that made it interesting.

The game is hard, you essentially control a group of minecraft minions to grind gather resources for you, to do this you assign them various jobs, these jobs require tools which you must have your minons craft.
Gameplay revolves around carefully balancing your resources and building defenses to keep out the ever increasing numbers of enemy creatures.
As time progresses, the dificulty level increases. the main problem is keeping your minions alive, run out of minions and you lose. run out of storage space and you lose (because you can't build anything)

So, those aspects of the game make it interesting and replayable, also they make the game challenging in the long term, the game never reaches the point where you can just sit back and know the enemy will never get in.

The features that drew me to the game in the first place are however not present in the current version. Specifically. there is no first person mode and you cannot travel to other lands to adventure away from your home town.

With development halted with minimal word from developers, those features may never return, in addition, several persistant crashes will likely never be fixed if development does not resume.
which is dissapointing because this game had heaps of promise.

Still, its worth it if you like town building. especially the minecraft elements where you can dig tunnels and build things using blocks.

Early Access Review

Edit: i had to change my recommendation to a negative because the game appears to be abandoned. The dev has never once updated or communicated since it was released on steam and now the website is offline - seems abandoned, another EA fail.

However! The rest of my original review is below and it still holds true. The game is great as it is, but it will likely not get any more updates, so I HAVE to thumbs down in good concience.

I have somewhere between 200-3oo hours into T&S over the last few months, and i really do love to play the game. It's one of those games I should set an alarm because 5 hours can go by and i will not even notice until I am parched and my stomach is growling.

Currently it is very playable and stable. The systems are all there and work quite well, as an EA game, it's in great shape technically and gameplay-wise.

Mod friendly - install mods if you want no enemies, kill enemies, permanent daylight, you name it. Copy a .dll to your save folder and that's it to install mods.

So you juggle professions, resources, defences, weapons, walls, increasingly dangerous hostiles in the wild who want to slaughter you all. A trader comes by now and then randomly, and depending on a bunch of factors (food, wealth etc) a new migrant may show up and join the town if you let them.

Settlers have random traits both good and bad (strong back, bad vision, etc) that make them a little better for certain jobs. You mine, farm, craft, build structures and walls, herd animals, all while keeping a sharp eye on the surroundings

Protip: Game start; make sure your miners mine stone very first thing, not dirt. Make the Stonemason build pick axes very first thing. reason is the picks will break randomly, and if you haven't got more, you're screwed somewhat. Get stone, make several picks, then make stone tools or storage or whatever you want.

Pros:
-Planning is key
-Massive replayablility & restarting is fun to try new ideas.
-Surviving a nasty Necromancer attack is a great feeling!
-Soundtrack is beautiful; sounds of chopping, hoeing, digging, combat etc all sound great.
-How each game plays out is really up to the player. Fortify and turtle? Go underground for a network of caves? Build in the sky? You can go nuts with creativity, check screenshots tab above!
-Each game you can do a little better as you fail, adapt and try again with what you learn, it's great.
-There is a definite learning curve, some people like this (I do)

Cons:
-Still needs optimization, late game the fps can suffer with many settlers
-Occasional bugs here and there that may require a reload, but nothing major/gamebreaking type.
-There is a definite learning curve, some people like this (I do), but the learning curve is a part of the game, you learn and do better next time.
-An entire day can disappear while you play (yep one of those games that can eat a whole Saturday no problem ;)

When I was a kid I loved playing Oregon Trail, and on the occasion where I didn't die from dysentery and made it all the way to Orgeon I always wondered where it left off. It turns out you leave off in the lands of Timber and Stone. I've tried other city builders (I'm looking at you Dwarf Fortress) and while I found them fun they lacked direction (and what exactly is ,,@''' mean?), T&S so far has added direction, an easy learning curve that ramps up to harder things (four hours in my first village was wiped by a pack of wolves, next round definitely need to skip heavier duty walls and just get anything up).

I'm only 4 hours into playing this, but so far have enjoyed it emensily (so much so that I bothered for the first time to write a review).

*** 64 Hour Update, Problems, so many problems ***

Combat AI has to get fixed to maintain a recommendation. Once you're day 40+ in the game can quickly grind to a hault. Sure you loose a few people, it happens, it sucks, but try recovering....

Here's the problem:

1) Your troop AI is stupid, for lots of reasons mentioned. Let alone non-combat townfolk who appear to be suicidal. So they easily get slaughtered.

2) You can't keep your troops together, so they easily get slaughtered.

3) You can't put them on a specific patrol route, to try to keep them together, so they easily get slaughtered.

4) You can't escort new villagers who come into the area, so they get slaughtered. And now you can't rebuild your population.

5) You can't escort traders, so they get slaughtered. And now your economy crumbles.

Essentially, because the combat AI is so poor the game hits a total roadblock. I managed to get up to 12 townfolk. Learned that you need an army, built it up, trained it (5 guys, nice armor, all lvl 11+ infrantry), and because of all the above randomness dropped down to 2.

Thankfully my core tradesman are safe inside the walls, but with only two guards left they'll only be that way until the next necromancer comes to town since I can no longer get citizens to come my town safely.

In short, the game is lots of fun at first, then you're toast unless you enjoy micro-micro-micro managing (e.g. pause the game, set your troop movement for a few tiles, play, pause, rinse-repeat).

I love this game, though I've only played it for roughly 18 hours since it has been released on steam I've spent countless of hours playing it before.
The game is fairly difficult and it takes some time to get used to in my opinion but once you figure out how everything works it becomes quite easy to set up a thriving settlement. (that is until you encounter a necromancer who keeps summoning skeletons inside your walls)

A few things I love about this game are.

- A fair diversity, there are quite some classes yet not that many,
the easier tools break and better tools that won't, require resources,which can be hard to get by or scarce,  and professions at certain levels meaning some professions are still a worthwhile investment even later on in game,

- Freedom to build/create/destroy/design as I desire

- Enemy difficulty progresses compared to how wel your settlement fares

- The new fog of war-ish, making enemies invisible unless one of your settlers can actually see them (even though they have a 360 degree sight radius) making it a bit more difficult to prepare for enemies, and in my opinion thus more interesting,

- Enemies not being allies with eachother, this compared with the previous point can however suprise me with suddenly finding piles of corpses on the map when looking around. (this was not the case before T&s got released to steam and made it really annoying when I got several types of enemies attacking my settlement at once)

- Siege weapon(s).. though there is only one for now, it's still awesome to have ballistas guarding your gate

- Inventory management (speaks for itself, though it can be a bit buggy at moments when one does take the items yet won't use them when they should)




There are a few things I'm personally disappointed with which are.

-The fact they turned sleeping into a thing to do when wounded instead of, whenever the settles were fatigued or scheduled to sleep,

-That they took out the adventurer class, even though this one did not have such a great purpose and it did not work that great, (not certain if they just took it out to be fixed or not to be completely honest) but it was great to walk through my settlement as one of my settlers.

- Archers, when set to train using a  practise target, tend to shoot the moment they can see the target, thus hitting fellow settlers or constructions if said archer moved for a bit to gather new equipment/food

- Archers quickly losing too much morale if there are too many enemies in sight when alone, even if enemies arent pursuing and could easily be picked off one by one from a distance




As for other things, I'm glad to see they added a few tips on how the game works, though from the reviews I read people still seem to miss a few things, hence I figure I'll mention a few things that might be good to know.

- '[' & ']'  should help you cycle through your settlers rather easily
- 'U' should give you an overview of your settlement & settlers and quickly assign roles.


If you love town sims I would most definitely recommend Timber and Stone

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeen following this game since the Alpha. About 2 years ago the game was a very challenging and slow paced RTS. I'm glad to say the game has changed from that for the better, while sticking to its roots. At its core the game is still a Survival RTS (though RTS is debatable due to the much appreciated inclusion of time control) Your party of units can all cycle through every different class, which is something that's very nice. It's still very challenging, but not player hostile. From day 1 you begin encountering easy to kill mobs, Wolves, Goblins, Skeletons, things of that sort. Learning how the combat works is something extremely important, otherwise you will fail very early. To get through the earlygame you will need 3 main things, a source of food (Farmers, Fishers, Herders, and Foragers on larger maps) an income of construction resources (Wood, stone, ores) and an understanding of preplanning. More or less you'll spend your first few ingame days digging, obtaining food, and building 1 main shelter, the location of which will be very important. You need to keep all of your units alive until you get a road setup, when you'll start getting travelers to join your party. This point is where the midgame starts. You get more and more settlers, and start expanding your settlement. Mobs spawn rates will become much higher as the game goes on, and until you get to the very lategame when you practically have armies of units, it's not worth the loss in productivity to kill off the mobs. It still has a rather steep learning curve, but the ingame tutorials will teach you everything you need to know (something very welcome in an RTS) and it's rather encouraging of trial and error. One of my few complaints is that the game is slow paced by design, which makes earlygame very tedious as you have typically 1 miner, 2 foodgatherers, 1 lumberjack, and 3 units rotating between Blacksmith/Stone Mason/Carpenter/Builder/Engineer.

The game is fun and entertaining and scratches an itch that other sandboxes don't do.
However in its current state I would say save your money. Game lacks a good AI, UI, tutorial, and does not offer ways for all in game classes to level in a sufficient manner (example would be the Engineer which is at early levels only really allowed to build a LOT of training dummies to level.)

The game is incomplete and at its current state can be fun for a bit until you realize all the limitations it has.

I would give the game 8/10 if the developer would do so work on the combat AI.
There is a lot of great stuff in this game but having your society crippled due to the loss of a few key people all because they do stupid stuff and then die just ruins any virtues this game has.

Archers on high castle walls fleeing wolves on the otherside of the moat. They are totally safe so why are they fleeing? Have the wolves some how developed the ability to shoot lasers from thier eyes or something?
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=619167870&fileuploadsuccess=1

Archers, each with 12 arrows and a bow, leaving combat to restock their arrow supply after firing only  3 or 4 arrows.

Archers/infantry standing next weapon rack refusing to uquip weapons, composite bows/broard swords because they would prefer to charge foes with clubs alone.

Spearman inside the castle ready to repell invaders charging out the front gate one by one to their doom. Firstly I am pretty impressed as I didnt realize that they posessed x-ray vision but could they just obay orders an hold their ground. Secondly isnt the front gate suposed to be locked and bared in time of war; not that it will help much as it has the structural integrity of cardboard, wet cardboard.
(this is the one that ruins the whole game)

Workers leaping off gastle walls into the moat so they can stab an enemy. Thumbs up for brawery, two thumbs down for common sense.

Farmers armed with clubs charging groups of skeletons. and this is after I have manually ordered them to withdraw to a safe location. The skeletons probably had it comming since they trampled the wheat but dude we can plant more next season. I would have hated to see what would have happened had they trampled the corn.

Infantry retreating through enemy forces and being butchered to a man. Just because your waving a white flag does not mean that the undead horde will respect  it. And wolves didnt sign the Geneva convention, some thing about not having hands or such.

Woodcutters strolling into a warzone to chop some trees. I have heared of work ethic but this is just carrying it too far. Normally I change the profession of non-combatants to traders and they all assemble in the main hall awaiting the next trade caravan as there is no command telling people to seek shelter in time of battle. Perhapse the developer will allow be to make a town bell which I can ring to alert everyone that the village is under attack. It would give me something to do with all that bronze.

Infantry charging foes only to have your own archers shoot them in the back. It was dark, I didnt see him, I thought he was a wolf, yeah thats right a wollf carrying a spear and a shield.

People who have recently had their ocupation changed to archer notequiping a bow and arrows and being forced to manually tell each archer to maintain a bow and arrows.

Having the ability to 'hold your ground' and stab / shoot anything that comes withing range would solve a lot of those issues. And just because you have a club does not make you an infantry soldier.
Fix the combat AI and this game is 8/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI got a lot more hours logged before the steam release. Is the game abandoned? I hope not but it does appear that way, but with that said I still think the game is worth every 12 dollars that is being asked. For me I had no major issues and everything that was promised as far as I am concerned was delivered on. Would I like to see more done? Of Corse I would, but all the negative reviews and accusations folks made in the post are completely unfounded. The game starts, it runs with no crashes (for me at list), and I put in 17 hours over 2 -3 days of playing it on steam. I gotten less time from so called tipple A titles which cost a lot more than 12 dollars. What the game delivers and delivers is well is a sandbox experience to build your own community from scratch. I have not experience this level of freedom ever before in my games and I played a great deal of the. I did play populist, and dungeon keeper titles, and many more but none have come this close to giving you ultimate freedom. The only “bug” I did run in to is the lack of villagers. I have a game on day 43 and not a single villager has joined me yet. Now here is a work around for this I found that seems to work. It appears villagers will not join till you lose one character at list. Once one of your villagers die and you get the replacement your population will start to grow as intended after that. Not sure if this works for others or not but it seems to be a solution in my case.
